headline: Opinion Taking the Mr. Wimpy approach to the gas tax
sentences: They remind me of J. Wellington Wimpy, who famously said, “I’ll gladly pay you Tuesday for a hamburger today.” In this case, it would be a discount for the cost of filling up your gas tank.
Mark Kelly (D-Ariz.) and Maggie Hassan (D-N.H.) introduced a bill that would suspend the federal gas tax until the end of 2022.
It will raise taxes, transfer revenue from another source or reduce the scope or number of transportation funded projects.
What neither senator addressed is the result, which would be billions less going into the Highway Trust Fund.
A federal gas tax holiday would result in Uncle Sam not collecting $0.18 for every gallon of gas purchased.
Tuesday might never come for motorists who have to pay for these proposed goodies.
This is a critical source of funding for highway and transit projects.
The loss of billions would have to be made up at a later date.
The Highway Trust Fund already faces financial difficulties.
Congress will have to decide how to make up the lost money.
Motorists and transit riders will be the losers.
